text:
SPEAKER 1: Today, I have
Professor Monte Winslow with me. And Dr. Winslow
grew up in Canada

and received his
undergraduate degree from the University of
Victoria, in Canada.

He did his PhD
studies in Immunology, working with Dr. Jerry Crabtree,
at Stanford University,

before pursuing his
post-doctoral training with Dr. Tyler Jacks at MIT.

Dr. Winslow is currently
an associate professor of genetics and pathology
at Stanford University.

Dr. Winslow's research focuses
on understanding the mechanisms that drive cancer development,
progression, metastasis,

and therapy response. He's developed in
vivo mouse models that enable the isolation and genomic
characterization of cancer

cells and use these
models to contribute to our understanding of
cancer initiation, growth,

and progression. These studies have focused on
uncovering the molecular forces that contribute to the
development and progression

of the three most
metastatic and deadly cancer types, lung adenocarcinoma,
small cell lung cancer,

and pancreatic cancer. He's also contributed to the
development of novel cancer

modeling approaches that enable
rapid and quantitative analyses of the genetic drivers
of carcinogenesis.

His laboratory has
generated methods for somatic CRISPR/Cas9
mediated genome editing and use

these models to introduce
both gain and loss of function alterations in
somatic cells in vivo.

By incorporating increasingly
quantitative methods and powerful in vivo
methods, Dr. Winslow's

work in uncovering
general rules that govern tumor isolation,
growth, and progression--

excuse me. Dr. Winslow's work is
uncovering general rules that govern tumor isolation,
growth, and progression

across diverse tumor genotypes. So thank you for being here. And now, I'll pass it
over to Dr. Winslow.

MONTE WINSLOW: All right. Thank you, Jan, for
that introduction. And thank you everyone
who's joined this webinar.

What I want to do today is
really give broad introduction of how we and others have been
using CRISPR genome editing

to really understand
cancer better.

So what I want to do is
really three things today. I want to introduce
cancer genetics to you.

I want to introduce
genome editing. I'm going to, then, talk
about some applications of how

genome editing has contributed
to our better understanding of how cancer works.

And then I'll kind of end
with some future directions, where do I see this
going, and some sort of simple take-home messages
from this webinar today.

First, we'll talk about cancer
genetics and genome editing.

So despite there being
other huge global health problems right now, cancer
remains a tremendously high

in incidence. And it drives a lot of
mortality around the world. This is just showing the
metrics of that number of people

who get different
cancer types and die from these different
cancer types worldwide, each year, with lung, colon
cancer, stomach, liver, breast

cancer. Pancreatic cancer is the
right coming up next. So cancer remains a formidable
disease around the world.

But I want to show
this next topic, because despite the prevalence
of cancer in the United States,

in the world, we've actually
made pretty good progress over the last 50 years. So what this chart is
showing you is, on the bottom

axis is essentially--
well, let's look at the
left-hand axis first. This is a metric that
some of us people

think about, which is the
10-year survival rate. If a patient is diagnosed
with a certain cancer type, what's the chance they're going
to be live 10 years later?

And you can see that
different cancers have different 10-year survivals. But I was going to say,
the important thing is

on this axis on the
bottom, which is like, how much has that
percent, 10-year survival, changed in the last 50 years?

So for example, if you
look at the top right, you see prostate cancer. There's more than a 50%
increase in how long

people survive with prostate
cancer, what percent of people will survive 10 years. So for many of these cancers
that are moving to the right,

there's been great
advances in treatment. But there is some
that remain down at the bottom left, lung
cancer, pancreas cancer.

These are still extremely hard
to treat and where I think we need really new advances.

So cancer is fundamentally
a genetic disease. And what this means is that
within the genome of the cells,

of the normal cells
that become cancer, there are alterations
that occur,

and those alterations that
really initiate cancer and drive cancer progression.

In these different
type of alterations that can occur in the genome,
they might be mutations.

This means that there's a single
letters in the genome-- single, we call them nucleotides--
that get changed.

There can be
structural alterations. There can be whole big pieces
of chromosomes that get stuck to each other or flip around.

And there can also be extra
numbers of chromosomes. Maybe, we get three copies
of certain chromosomes

that for some reason
this helps drive cancer. So regardless of what
these alterations are,

there's really three
outcomes that you can get. The alteration,
the genomic change

can either, essentially,
inactivate the gene that it occurs in. And the reason that
this can cause cancer

is, maybe, these are genes
that normally stop cells from growing. Now, if you lose that
gene, they might grow more.

Those alterations can increase
the activity of that protein. Usually, we call
these oncogenes.

So you get a mutation,
and it turns something on that really drives the
cells to now become a cancer.

In rare cases, these
alterations can completely alter the function of a gene. So there's a relatively
simple relationship here.

Genomic alterations
can drive these changes in your normal cells that
can then lead to cancer.

Despite the sort of
simplicity of that,

there are many complexities. One is that, many tumors have
lots of alterations in them,

up to tens of thousands of these
alterations in their genome. Some of them might be
important for driving cancer.

People call those
driver mutations. While others might not
actually have any effect. It just happened to have
gotten mutated along the way,

and they don't do anything. People call those passengers. But in many cases,
it's not clear

which alterations
in different genes are drivers or passengers. It's also the case
that there are

many different
genomic alterations in different tumors. So tumors from no two
patients will be identical.

So there's a lot of
complexity in trying to understand which
of those alterations might be functionally
important, might really be

important for driving cancer. Then not only are
these tumors different, but there's different
combinations of genes.

Maybe, one patient
has these five genes, and another patient
has two of those but also three or five others.

So there's a lot
of complexity there in trying to understand
how these alterations in the genome of cancer
cooperate to drive
the way that cancer acts.

So as you can imagine from the
understanding of the genetics

of human cancer that new tools
that allow us to purposefully alter the genome to
ask questions of,

if I create that mutation that
sometimes occurs in cancer, does it cause cancer? Does it help cancer grow?

These are those type of
questions that these new tools can really help us address. So the tool we're going
to talk about today

is CRISPR genome editing. And the example we
use is CRISPR/Cas9.

It was one of the
first ones discovered, and this is the prototype
for how this works. These are actually
natural systems

that occur in bacteria that now
we can use to better understand genetics.

The way these work in
bacteria is actually that-- you can see on the left,
there's these Cas genes.

These are CRISPR
associated genes. These are proteins that are
encoded in bacteria, naturally.

And what these
proteins do is, they bind to a small RNA
molecule, shown over here,

called a guide RNA. And when that protein in that
RNA molecule come together, then it can actually
help protect the bacteria

from these phage. And phage are essentially
virus that infect bacteria. So this is a way
that the bacteria

can defend itself, essentially,
against this virus. But what became clear is that,
when you have the ability

to express a protein,
or these Cas proteins, and this small RNA, called the
guide RNA, then if you can cut

DNA in the bacteria,
yes, it's a phage, but if you could use
it in mammalian cells, you could potentially
cut the DNA in a cell

and do different
things with it, maybe, create mutations
that we can then understand how they function.

So this is what
people have done. It ends up that there's
really only two components that you need for this
CRISPR/Cas9 system.

You need this Cas9 protein,
and you need this small RNA, called a guide RNA.

Cas9 is a type of protein
called the nuclease. In this case, it
means it can cut DNA.

And the sgRNA is
this RNA molecule that can target Cas9 to
anywhere in the genome.

This RNA molecule is actually
the part that binds to the DNA and specifies
where it will bind.

And it's what we
call "programmable." You can make it have
any sequence you want. And when you make that guide
RNA have a certain sequence,

it'll go to a certain
region of the genome, and then Cas9 will cut
the DNA at that location.

And the reason that's
useful is, when you create a double
strand break in the DNA, it then undergoes these
natural repair process,

just like our DNA often, as it
gets broken it can be repaired. But that repair is
not always perfect.

So you can get these small
insertions and deletions that then, essentially,
break that gene.

So we now have the
ability to express these two components,
Cas9 and a guide RNA,

create a double strand break
anywhere in the genome that can be repaired. And in some cases, it
will inactivate that gene.

So you can see now that
we have the ability to create these
alterations in the genome

much like those that naturally
occur in human cancer. And I'll tell you how we've been
using that to better understand

how essentially cancer forms
or what are the driving forces. The one key thing
here that you'll

see in all of my examples is
that you need a guide RNA. You need the Cas9 protein. You need to somehow get
that into the cells.

And then we can look
for the effects. And we can learn
about what these genes we're inactivating actually do.

And also, as you've
probably seen, I've laid out a very
complex group of diseases,

all these different cancer
types, and a genome editing tool that allows us
to start investigating

how those genes function. So this has really
been a perfect match in the development of
a tool and the ability

to investigate a
complex disease. So next thing I want to do is
talk about some applications

of genome editing that have
really accelerated our ability to understand, I think, two very
important aspects of cancer.

So the first thing that
I want to talk about is, it's not so
much trying to say, hey, these genes are
broken in cancer,

and we want to break them
and see what they do, but rather present how
people have been using genome editing to
understand what we often

call cancer dependencies. And this is saying, what do
cancer cells really need? And if you could, for example,
inactivate a bunch of genes,

you might learn a lot of
cancer cells depend on, and then that might be
a route to understand

how to have drugs that can
better kill cancer cells. I'll show you a few examples. And then the second
main thing I want

to tell you about is really
altering genes of interest in cells to try to understand
which of those genes

drive cancer growth and
different phenotypes, different ways those cells act.

So first, let's talk about
uncovering cancer dependencies. So what I laid out
a few slides ago was the idea that if you can
get a guide RNA targeting

a certain gene and
Cas9 into a cell, you can then
inactivate that gene

and you can learn
about what it does. So in a very simple
way, you can imagine taking a cancer cell line.

These are cells from
human, often tumors, that we can now grow
in dishes in the lab.

And you could take
that cell line-- if you express a
guide RNA targeting a certain gene and Cas9,
you can get a cell line that

is essentially identical
to the initial one except that it lacks, maybe,
one gene that you think might be important.

And then we can look
and see if there's any effect on those cells. And what could the effect be? It could be that
the cells all die.

That seems like an important
gene for cancer cells. It could be that the
cells grow slower. They could respond
different to therapy.

Could really be anything
that-- in the lab here, we can think about looking at
it and ask questions about how

does that one gene function. This is really the
basis of a lot of what we understand about cancer.

A lot of what we
understand about biology is saying, how do we
inactivate a gene,

and then see what happens. You might imagine saying, well,
if you can delete one gene,

maybe you can delete
a lot of genes all at the same time
in different cells, and you can learn
about what they all do.

This has been really a
tremendous application of CRISPR/Cas9 genome
editing, saying, in this case,

let's take a cancer cell line
and we'll take tens of millions of those cells and let's get--

so that every cell has a
different guide RNA express it. All these cells will
inactivate different genes.

We can then grow them for
a certain amount of time and just ask the question
of what's the effect.

In this case, the
effect could say, if we inactivate
some of these genes, maybe this library that
we express actually

inactivates all the
genes in the genome. But individual genes
in different cells, we grow them for some time.

Some of those cells
will grow less well. And there's ways to
understand that at the end

of the experiment
to say, oh, here's the 100 genes that really
hurt these cancer cells. Oh, here's some genes
that maybe help them grow.

So these are the
applications where you can start looking
more broadly at how different classes
of genes impact

cancer growth or different
ways that they behave using these cell line studies.

Mike Bassik, in the Genetics
department at Stanford, where they took this one
step further, and said,

well, we don't want
to just inactivate one gene in these
cancer cells, and we don't want to inactivate a
bunch of individual genes.

They did an experiment
to see, if we delete two genes in every cancer
cell, these cells grown

in dishes in the lab,
what will the outcome be? And the important
thing here is that,

which genes do they
try to inactivate as combinations, as pairs? And ends up that they
decided to target genes that

are potential drug targets. So they have guide RNAs that
target these potential drug

targets. And they made
pairwise combinations of all these different
RNAs to target essentially
pairs of drug targets.  This is the layout of their--

we call them screens that they
did, where they have one guide RNA targeting a drug
target, another guide

RNA targeting
another drug target. And they made a huge number,
21,000 different combinations

of these. They can put them into
this cancer cell line, and then all the
pairs are represented.

They grow them for some time,
just like I said before. And then, perhaps,
there's some pairs that now get lost from this sort
of population of cancer cells,

suggesting that
inactivating those two genes really hurts the cancer cells.

This is a plot from their paper. But the important part to
look at is really down here. These are the pairs
of genes that when

you inactivate them really
hurt this cancer cell line. And I want to
highlight one, which

I'm going to show a little
bit on the next slide, but this is BCL2L1,
and MCL-1 These are important proteins that
normally keep the cell alive.

But it appears that if you
inactivate both of them here, you really have a huge impact
on probably killing these cancer

cells. So the reason to do
this whole experiment

was there's a certain
logic here that says that, if you can delete
pairs of genes using CRISPR--

remember, this is entirely
impossible without these sort of genome editing tools. If you can delete pair
of genes, maybe it

tells you about pairs of drugs
that you should be using, because you
identified those genes and what they control
as being important

in this genetic screen
that Mike Bassik's lab did. So then, next experiment,
they did was to say, well,

we now know which two
genes are important, so what if we use
two drugs that also inhibit into the proteins
of those genes make?

And here's the result.
This is the percent of cells that are dead. That's what the axis is showing.

And you have no drug. There's very few dead cells. You have a drug that inhibits
one of these proteins. You get a little bit of death.

The other one a little
bit of cancer cell death. But if you inhibit both
of them, all of a sudden, you almost entirely
kill the cancer cells.

So by doing this pairwise
genome editing screen,

they were able to find
combinations of, in this case, drugs that might be effective
against this cancer type.

So these are some, I
think, nice examples

of how people have used genome
editing in very broad scale, 20,000 genes,
20,000 combinations

to really try to understand
what do cancer cells depend on. There's been huge efforts across
hundreds of different cancer

cell lines from
different cancer types to understand these
dependencies as it might really

help the development
of novel therapies, really understanding how
to hurt cancer cells.

So the next thing I
want to talk about is really using
CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing to understand the
driving forces of cancer.

So yes, cancers
have many mutations. But which of these are actually
important in driving cancer?

So one thing that I
would like to point out is that cancer is really
a complex process that

occurs within sort
of the environment in which the tumor is growing. So shown here on the left is
an individual normal cell.

And this is what
cancer comes from. And there can be certain genomic
alterations, these changes that

occur in those
initial cells that drive the initial
expansion of those cells,

and maybe they're not behaving
quite like they're supposed to. And then other
genomic alterations can occur over time,
more of these mutations,

and then the tumor gains
the greater ability to grow.

There's also a lot
of interactions with other cells within the
sort of microenvironment of that tumor is.

And this is one reason why
we and others have really focused on trying to understand
cancer growth within the in

vivo context, within the
context of an animal that is growing these tumors.

We think that some of
these other interactions are really critical
for understanding how cancer develops.

Remember, I told you
that for, at least, CRISPR/Cas9 genome
editing, all you

need is to be able to get the
guide RNA in the cell, Cas9 in the cell, and you need
some sort of delivery method

to get those two
things in there. So you can imagine being
able to deliver those to, again, that single
normal cell, in our case,

within mouse models
of human cancer. And if you can get those
into that single cell, you can then ask the
question, OK, does

that genomic alteration
that you just created now drive really expansion
of those cells,

drive their bad behavior,
allow them to grow particularly quickly, which would
indicate that that gene is

important in cancer?  So we started doing
this many years ago.

And the first
cancer type that we modeled using CRISPR/Cas9 genome
editing within these mouse

models of human cancer is
actually pancreas cancer. In the way we did this is,
we had the Cas9 engineered

within the mouse. So essentially, every
cell in the mouse has the ability to express Cas9.

And then we could
deliver the guide RNA component, this programmable
RNA, on a viral vector.

We use these very frequently. You can engineer
these viruses to do what you want to just deliver,
in this case, this guide

RNA and one other
important component here. And then we're able
to deliver this virus

into the pancreas of
one of these mice, and start asking questions about
how these certain genes may

or may not contribute to
pancreas cancer growth. We actually did this all in
a model for the aficionados

where all the cells will
express an oncogene called KRAS, and then we use CRISPR
to alter other genes,

ask if they normally
suppress cancer growth. We also engineer these mice in a
way where all the little tumors

will glow red. So in this case,
this is a pancreas from a mouse where all
these small red regions are

these oncogenic KRAS-driven,
very, very small, pancreas tumors.

But if we used
CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing to inactivate this gene that
my lab cares about called LKB1,

it's a potential
tumor suppressor. But what we found
in the pancreas is that, if you
delete that gene, now rather getting these really
tiny pancreas tumors,

you get these huge
pancreas tumors. This is clearly a gene
that is incredibly important in pancreas cancer.

When you delete it,
you get bigger tumors. We can look at this in
number of different ways. This is actually a
section of a pancreas.

This is pretty much
what a normal pancreas looks like, yours and mine. This is what it looks like.

But now, if you delete this
gene using CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing in those cells
within the pancreas,

where there's not
a cell line we're transplanting-- we're
actually genetically altering single cells within
the pancreas of this animal.

Now, we get something
that looks very different. And in fact, this looks
like some variation

of human pancreas cancer. The key feature here is that
what CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing

allowed us to do is assess
the importance of this gene very quickly. There are other ways to do this.

They would have taken us
three or four years to do. But in this case, we could
do it in a matter of months.

So that, for us,
is a huge advance. That's a huge advance for
what our lab is able to do and other labs
are able to do far

as understanding how these genes
impact cancer growing in vivo.

But I kind of started
this talk by telling you that cancer was very complex. Many different
genes are altered.

Many different combinations
of genes are altered. And then I just showed an
example where we went back, and we deleted one gene, and we
celebrated, and we are happy.

But how do we now start
thinking about using genome editing to understand
more about the complexity?

So what I told you
it is certainly true. If this is sort of a
textbook model of cancer,

where there's a single normal
cell that then gets an oncogene and grows, and these
tumor suppressor

genes, these genes that
normally suppress cancer growth, are getting deleted. We can just look at human data.

And we can say, well,
lots of human cancers have been sequenced. In this case, when we
talk about lung cancer.

And you can look
at the frequency. What percent of
human tumors have an activation of certain genes?

And here's the ones we're
going to talk about, a list of 11 genes. And they're mutated at different
frequencies in human cancer,

and some of them
are already genes that we know are tumor
suppressors, and some of them are not. And so we decided to try
to develop a system where

we can inactivate
all 11 of these genes in different tumors, but a way
where we can understand which

of them are important
for driving cancer. So what I showed
you in the pancreas,

we've also able
to do in the lung. And that would be to say, take
a viral vector-- remember, this is how we're
delivering the guide

RNAs to inactivate this gene
LKB1 that we like so much. If you deliver that to
the lung of a mouse,

you can generate
lung tumors if it's a context where it also
has its oncogenic KRAS, and that's fine.

But what we decided to do was
say, well, what if we made up a pool of these lentiviral
vectors, these viral vectors,

and in each one,
we put a guide RNA targeting a different
tumor suppressor? Then if we delivered
it to mice, we

can actually develop,
in this case, 11 different flavors of tumors. We call them
genotypes because they

assess how all, for example, 11
of these genes might function. That's exactly what
we were able to do.

We can deliver this pool of
vectors to the mouse's lung.

We can generate all the
different genotypes. Each initial cell really
only gets one of these virus.

So every tumor only
deletes one of these genes. And then we developed
methods based

on high throughput
sequencing to really quantify the size of every single
tumor in the mouse. Maybe, they get 1,000.

We can quantify them all. We can understand how many
cancer cells they have. And we can know which
of these 11 genes

was inactivated in each tumor. We could take that
information and then really try to understand the
impact of these genes.

But even before we
did that, we knew that some of the genes
in here were really important in driving cancer.

This is actually a
lung low from a mouse. And this mouse
does not have Cas9. Remember, when there's no
Cas9, none of those genes

will be inactivated. And when there's
oncogenic KRAS, you get some small
little red tumors. I hope you can see here.

When the mice do have
Cas9 and all those tumors suppressors are being
deleted in individual tumors,

now we saw many
more large tumors. Certainly, some of these
genes that we inactivated are really important in
normally slowing down growth.

And when we get rid of them,
the tumors grow faster.  We analyze this in
many ways, but this

is the sort of simple way to
show it where the-- here are all the genes we inactivated. And if they're dark blue, it
means when we deleted them,

the tumors grew really big. The ones that are lighter
blue, when we deleted them, the tumors grew a
little bit faster.

And actually, there
white ones, when we deleted or
inactivated those genes, it had no impact on growth.

So that was also
interesting to us. So we can make some conclusions. One is that we actually
identified novel genes.

We identify genes that
were not known before to suppress cancer.

And in this pooled setting,
we could find those genes. Was interesting to us
that some of these genes

were actually not important,
at least in cancer how we had modeled it.

And I would say that the
effect of inactivating different genes, like whether
they had big effect or smaller

effect, it didn't correlate
with how frequently they're mutated in human cancer. And the reason we
think this is important

is, there may be
genes that are altered in a small percent
of human patients.

And in fact, those
genes are incredibly important in those
individual tumors. So we need these
type of approaches

where we can look at
large numbers of genes to really start looking at those
that are rare in human tumors but might still
be very important.

But I also told
you that, remember, it's not-- in human cancer, it's
not a single gene gets mutated. There's going to be combinations
of genes that get mutated.

So in human lung adenocarcinoma,
this is the subtype that we're looking at. I showed you this before. Here is the frequency in
which these genes are mutated.

These ones that I just
showed you the impact of. But in fact, if you say,
well, there's this gene p53.

It's incredibly important. See here, it's mutated almost
half a lung adenocarcinoma. So if you look at human tumors
that have p53 mutations, oh,

but they also have mutations
in all of these other genes. So there's pairwise mutations
in these potential tumors

suppressors. And its the same if we look at
another subset of human lung cancer, those that mutate
this gene called LKB1,

they also have mutations
in all these genes. So this is a sort of
glimpse of this complexity I was talking about,
where there's pairs

of genes that are inactivated. So we did another
experiment where instead of deleting one
gene, we deleted the pairs

and essentially created
this 3 by 11 matrix that I'm showing you
here, where we can then

begin to understand, when
you delete combinations of genes, what happens? Remember, we don't want to
delete combinations of genes

just for fun. We want to understand,
when there's a human tumor that has that
pair of genes inactivated,

is that in fact working to
drive the growth of the tumor? I think you can see that from
the sort of blue coloring.

And in some cases, when
you delete pairs of genes, the tumors grow much
better than if they only had one gene inactivated.

So it ends up that-- this comes to a
conclusion where we say, the effect of
inactivating these genes,

how genes drive cancer, it's
really context dependent, really depends on what
other genes have already

been altered in the tumor. And this is something
that wasn't really previously solidly established.

So we've gone on with
these type of methods, now to delete 50 putative
tumor suppressors,

and start looking
at not only do they drive growth, which is kind
of what I was showing you before that's in the
middle, but do any of them

drive tumor initiation? How well a cell will go from
being a normal cell to being a cancer?

And then there's some
other features of cancer we've been able to
look at, but we're starting to develop more
complex maps like this,

where some of these genes-- you
see this one, the top right, called PTEN. It appears to be very
important in suppressing

cancer initiation and growth. So when you get rid of
it, there's more tumors and they grow faster.

And other genes here have
very different phenotypes, different effects of
deleting these genes.

So this is really what
we get excited about. Because now we can start looking
at large numbers of genes.

We can really
understand what they do in cancer growing, in this
case, in these mouse models.

And the important
thing to not forget is the only reason
we can do this is because of the development
and discovery of CRISPR genome

editing. This really easy way
to inactivate genes by just using Cas9
and this guide

RNA to target them,
create DNA breaks and ultimately
inactivate the genes.

I'd like to just talk
about one last thing which I think is
tremendously important. And this is the
question of, when you

have a population of patients-- we actually now have
widespread cancer genotyping,

which means that tumors
from many patients are being sequenced to find
out which genes are altered.

So for many, for example,
lung cancer patients, they come to the clinic and
we ultimately understand

all the genes that are mutated. There's also a lot of drugs,
as shown here on the right.

But one fundamental question
that is still extremely hard to tackle is, which drugs
should which patients get?

These patients have
different genes altered. And we have a lot
of different drugs. But which subset of patients
should get the red drug

and which should
get the other drug? So we've tried to use
our in vivo approaches to begin to address
this question.

I told you that we can take
this library of viral vectors, and we can initiate
tumors in mice that--

in this case, there
are essentially 12 different genotypes, 12
different flavors of tumors. So we did an experiment
where we took groups of mice

with all those different
tumors, and we treated them with different therapies. And then we did
our same approach

to look at the size
of every tumor. And this allows us
now to start asking questions about whether
there are the genes that

are mutated in the tumor
either make them more sensitive to certain
drugs, that would be good,

or more resistance
to certain drugs. That would also be good
to know, because it would say that if a patient, for
example, has this gene mutated,

they should probably not
be treated with that drug. The genotype of their tumor
will dictate the response

and that looks like, maybe, a
genotype that will not respond. So what we were able to
do is create sort of a map

like this where all the
different genes that we inactivated are shown
on the left-hand side,

and the different drugs
are shown on the bottom. And I'm going to show you
this sort of heat map. But what this really shows
is that any square that's red

means that tumors that
had that gene inactivated were resistant to the drug.

So for example, you can see
some of the dark red ones here, right? That would mean that if
you inactivate that gene,

the tumors really don't respond. Then the blue squares
mean that if you

have a tumor that has
inactivated that gene, they're, in fact, very
sensitive to that drug. So that would be good to know.

And the interesting thing for
us here was not necessarily the individual interactions
between the genes

and the drugs, but that there
were still many interactions. So these genes that we
could inactivate really

drive drug responses. And this suggests that
the genotype of the tumor, which of these
genes are altered,

might be a major determinant
of how well patients' tumors respond to different therapies.

And we would love to think
that these type of findings can help with precision
medicine, understanding how

the genotype of the tumor
might dictate and drive, which therapies
that respond best.

So I'd like to end with
some future directions where I see this going, at
least in our line of work, and then some take
home messages.

So what aspects of
cancer development do we think are
poorly understood

and where these genome
editing tools could help develop new understanding?

So this is sort of
a drawing that some of these people of cancer. At the top is the
cell, the normal cell,

the cancer came from. And then as it goes down,
those sort of plus signs are new mutations that occur.

And then sometimes they'll
be sort of different. They call them subclones. But different
pieces of the tumor

that are different
from one another. And that sort of these
different colors. So you can think about going
from a single normal cell, all

the way to the bottom,
where you have a very heterogeneous tumor.

So what do we still need
to be able to do better to understand cancer? As you can see with these plus
signs, these mutations, that

are occurring in the cancer over
time as it goes down the slide, it would be great to be able to
control when alterations occur.

So we generate one
mutation at the beginning, and at a later time points,
we can introduce others.

That would be really
important in understanding cancer evolution.

Human cancer is still more
complex than what we're modeling within the mouse.

In one level, the mouse that
we use, these type of models are actually very good. We can understand what genes do.

But it might be nice
to have systems develop even more complex
alterations like those

that occur in human cancer. I talked a lot today
about creating alterations

in DNA, these mutations or
these chromosomal changes. But there's a whole other
layer of complexity,

which is called epigenetics. This is where genes
get changed not by having mutations but
by other elements that

control their expressions. There's ways to
use genome editing to understand epigenetics.

These tumors, as
you can see here, there's a lot of
different colors. There's a lot of complexity
within an individual tumor. That's something
that we would love

to be able to understand
the meaning of. Maybe the different
colored clones here sort of helping each other,
that would be interesting.

And I think there's
still a huge need to better understand how the
genotype, how the genes that

are mutated actually dictate
therapeutic responses to better

understand precision
medicine type approaches. So with that, I'll
have my last slide

here of take home messages. One is that cancer is
really a complex genetic. There's lots of genes
that are altered.

And they drive the
way cancer behaves. And this is important
for us to understand.

Second is that CRISPR-based
genome editing, no, really, is accelerating our
ability to investigate

many different aspects
of cancer development, from cancer initiation,
growth, metastasis,

drug response, every
step along the ways now kind of benefiting
from being able to do

these types of experiments. And finally, I think that these
type of advances-- remember,

we went from being
able to inactivate one gene to inactivate
in cells and culture

20,000 genes, in
the mouse, 50 genes. These are huge advances.

And I would love to think
that some of these approaches are going to be important,
not only for understanding cancer, but thinking about
how to treat it better.

So thank you very much and
I'll pass it back over to Jan. SPEAKER 1: I want to start
off by just actually--

Dr. Winslow, can you

that we've seen in the

We don't need to go into
the ethical aspects of it. But if you could just
touch on that a little bit,

I think there's a few
questions about that. MONTE WINSLOW: Great Thanks. Yeah. So there's, obviously,
tremendous number

of things that can be done
with CRISPR or genome editing. And what we hear a lot about
is the germline editing,

altering organisms and-- but what we're really
thinking about here

is really separate from that. We're really thinking
about using this technology to understand cancer.

So like I give the example
where we have these cancer cell lines. Here it's just an
experiment that we can do within these cells to
ask what do they depend on,

what do they need
to keep growing. And then our work within
these, well, ours and others

is really altering the
genetics in adult cells

within these organs where we
want to understand cancer. So these are quite different.

I would say another
question that comes up quite
often is the thought that maybe we'll use
this particular cancer.

If you can really delete
any gene you want, you might think,
well, why don't we just get CRISPR into the cancer
cells, and we can cure it?

It ends up that this
is not an easy feat. It's not easy to get these
guide RNAs, for example,

into every cancer cell. So really the two
things I talked about today were
understanding which

cells are required in cancers
and then understanding the genetics of these how
we drive cancer initiation

and growth. SPEAKER 1: Great. Follow up question
to that is actually,

would the same approach work
for diseases other than cancer?

MONTE WINSLOW: Right. So cancer is-- if you
want to just think

about the best
application, cancer would be the best application. Because cancer is
a disease where

mutations occur in adult cells,
usually, and usually over time.

And we can delete those genes
or alter them in different ways and then look at
cancer phenotypes.

Many other diseases
are, perhaps, driven by complex genetics. But they're entirely--
but it's more

the genetics of the entire
organism or the entire person, not necessarily that a gene was
altered in an individual cell.

There are probably other
diseases like that. But in many cases,
I think there's different approaches
that could probably
be better in that regard. So I would say that--

I guess what that answer
was a little bit stuck on thinking about the in
vivo models that we use. But actually, there's
many applications

of CRISPR/Cas9 genome
editing to understand biology around other diseases. Maybe taking different cell
types like neurons or stem

cells, and then altering
them with CRISPR, and then asking questions
about what different genes do.

That's tremendously
useful for understanding what drives a lot of
different diseases, actually. So there's many different
ways to think about this.

But certainly, these
general approaches could be used to understand
many different diseases. Thanks.

SPEAKER 1: Great. You mentioned the

Can two different

MONTE WINSLOW: Oh, I see. Yes, right. If two tumors were or--

I think most people would
think about this slightly differently. I know in our models we generate
a lot of individual tumors,

as they grow, there's different

what we call subclones,

kind of different
parts of the tumor that have different genes altered. And it's certainly the case
that different subclones

could perhaps help each

then, it's entirely reasonable

that that would happen
but very poorly understood how there might be cooperation
across different subclones.

I hope I got that one right. SPEAKER 1: If we use
gene editing approach

in cancer treatment,

using CRISPR for actual cancer

it's very difficult

to get these required components
into all cancer cells. So you can't just say, well

and we're going to somehow
get Cas9 and a guide RNA into every single cancer cell. It'll delete that gene, and
the cancer will go away.

There's too many cancer cells. This sort of delivering those
things is, at this point,

not feasible. Now you might
imagine saying, well, what if there was a way
to get some CRISPR/Cas9,

now you have an impact on
all the surrounding cells. Maybe, you activate the immune
system or something like that.

I think that's the way
I would think about it more, which is
saying, well, is there a clever way to not have to
get these components into all

the cancer cells? And then the second part
of the question, I think, was sort of related to what's
the risk to the patient.

In a theoretical world
where you could do this,

I wouldn't see the-- I mean the risk is the same
as any sort of cancer therapy. There's going to be side
effects of having impact

on normal cells I
don't think there'll be a tremendously different
risk for this type of thing.

SPEAKER 1: All right. Now a lot of
questions are actually about the difference
between CRISPR

and using like RNAi methods. And some people were
wondering if what's

more specific in
terms of knock-down? What is better? What are the pros and cons?

Why is CRISPR a
better technology for what you're doing and being
able to knock down the genes?

MONTE WINSLOW: Right. OK. So RNAi, or RNA interference, is
a very different type of method

where you express RNA
that bind to genes that actually the RNA of genes
and reduce the expression.

So in that case-- and then, of course, CRISPR
is what I just talked about, where you have this Cas9 or
other protein or nuclease

and guide RNA. And you actually cut the genome,
and you inactivate that gene. So they're very different
for two reasons.

One is the RNAi is
transient, meaning that when your RNA
molecule is there,

it will reduce the
expression of the gene, but over time, it goes away. Whereas CRISPR/Cas9
genome editing,

because you're actually
altering the genome, is stable. So when you delete that
gene, like we did our models

or whatever system,
it will always be deleted from those cells. So that's one big difference.

Another difference is that
when you delete genes, they're really gone. They went from there to 0.

With RNAi, you're always
knocking down the genes, meaning that you're reducing
the expression, but probably,

not getting it to zero. So I think, which
method would be better,

kind of depends on
what you want to do. So in some of our
experiment settings, we really want to just
inactivate that gene,

have it be inactivated
forever and see what it does. There are different
therapeutic applications

where RNA interference
is already being used, I mean, even to essentially
knock down genes and help

with disease phenotypes. So they're very
different approaches. And they have different
pros and cons,

depending really on what
you're trying to do. Yeah. It's a very interesting
thing to think about,

how best to do it
experimentally or if you're thinking therapeutically, how
best to do it that way too. Thanks.

SPEAKER 1: No. Thank you. A couple other

MONTE WINSLOW: Right. Yeah. Exactly. So I mean, I think
one key thing is, what we start with
is really human data.

We start with an understanding
of the genes that are frequently mutated
in human tumors, in our case, human lung cancer.

And then those are
the alterations that we engineer in the mouse
lung epithelial cells, and then and then look for how they
do or do not drive cancer.

So at that level, the genetics
were sort of matching. There's been studies to look at.

For example, what does
the tumor look like? If we take our tumors
from the mouse model, we show them to our pathology
colleagues here at Stanford,

they'll tell us, oh,
yeah, looks like a subset of human lung cancer. So that seems good. And we've done
some other analysis

on mouse tumors that appear to
align with human lung cancer. So there's several
analysis people

have done that give us
faith that these models are recapitulating at least
aspects of human cancer.

If you think, it's
really important also that these tumors
in the mouse models are developing entirely
in the natural setting,

from a single cell all the way
perhaps to a metastatic cancer with all the normal
sort of interactions.

And this is a feature that-- I mean, I do think the mouse is
really quite similar to human.

Lots of what we
understand about disease biology, developmental biology
has come from the mouse.

So we do think about this. But I think it's a
pretty, actually,

parallel system to the
human, but a system where we can control things. We can delete genes.

And we can ask what they do. We can give therapies
and see what happens. So yup.

SPEAKER 1: OK. Great. And then one last question. A few people were
interested in how

you're actually getting
CRISPR and the guide RNAs into the cells. So it's more a little bit
more of a technical question,

but if you could just expand

MONTE WINSLOW: Oh. Yeah. Right. So for the approaches
that I showed where we have these mouse
models of human cancer,

we actually have-- the
mice are engineered in a way where they have
the ability to express Cas9

in any cell that we needed. So that's actually within
the germline of the mouse and there's these
strains of mice that

have the ability to do that. So Cas9 is within the mouse. And then the way we deliver
the guide RNA and other things

that we want is through
these viral vectors. So the reason we call them
virus is, virus can replicate,

and we all know how that goes. These are essentially
engineered viral vectors,

meaning they kind
of are like a virus, and they can deliver
something to a cell. But they can never replicate.

So people use this
a lot experimentally to essentially get
things into cells. And we use this type of
virus called the lentivirus,

but essentially, just as a
vector to take what we want and then get it into the cell.

So that's how we do it. I would say across
many different systems, there's a lots of
different ways to do it.

So for example, we all know
that you can package mRNA in lipid nanoparticles now.

And you can deliver it to cells. That's how the Pfizer and
Moderna vaccines work. So there are different ways to
get what you want into cells,

and it-- yup. Exactly. It's slightly different in
vivo and in cell culture, but there's lots of methods
but probably depends

what you want to do. Great. Thanks. SPEAKER 1: No. Thank you. And if you would
